								Firstly, I would like to applaud the developers at Nerd Kingdom on a great job in developing a terrific game so far.  It must be, I’ve logged over 900 hours since purchasing the game in September 2014. Apparently, I don’t have a life.  To put this into perspective, that’s about 6 hours of game playing per day over the past five months.Like most people, I enjoy playing open world sandbox survival games, exploring, crafting, mining, but mostly building things.  TUG offers all of these things, but with a very rich non-blocky interactive environment where you become immersed into your surroundings. The world ambient sounds seem to add to this immersion, leading you to start foraging for supplies right away to survive at least the first night.  The environment sounds have you looking over your shoulder for critters that might be sneaking up on you or a sound that stops you in your tracks wondering what is that?, is it going to eat me?, do I run away?Once you start the game, you immediately find yourself exploring or running away from a critter because you haven’t crafted a weapon yet and thinking that the rock in your hand doesn’t seem adequate enough to defend yourself, or just wanting to see what is over the next hill or to watch a spectacular sunrise or sunset.  Once you feel safe you notice that you are now hungry so you begin foraging for food to eat.  My mom always wanted me to be a vegetarian.  You now notice that your backpack of many things is full containing mostly different types of rocks, a few sticks and some vines. You begin throwing these items onto the ground to see what can be crafted. Now that you are armed to the teeth with stone tools and weapons; including a hoe and shovel, you are more likely to begin building something such as a hole in the ground to hide in or experimenting with the various available building materials (limited at the moment) to construct your dream home-base to venture forth from into the world of TUG. One thing I like about TUG so far is that there are no zombies, yet.  I don’t like zombies as they sneak-up on you while you are busy doing something and scare the ___ out of you, much like the forest children do in this game, the kinokojin. Although I have experienced many game crashes mostly with the indev version, lost files, and other game bugs, TUG is still a great game so far and knowing it will get even better with future updates.  Putting all that aside, the following are some suggestions that would be nice to see implemented into the game; however, some of these suggestions may not be possible:1.	Crafting a compass. This is not really necessary, but crafting a compass would be a cool way to explore the world of TUG for those who need one.  Based on your compass marches or hikes, you could craft area maps.  I found that knowing where the sun rises and sets in the game (east and west) and using landmarks, whether made or natural, you can navigate throughout the world quite reasonably. 2.	Crafting a bow and arrows.3.	The gathering and or crafting of new building materials.4.	Doors, windows and furniture.5.	Adding a smaller block size in addition to the two we already have for adding building trim details.6.	Once water is introduced into the game, will seedlings be able to swim?7.	Crafting a boat to float down that lazy river or to see if you can survive boating over a waterfall or white water rafting.8.	Crafting a fishing rod to go fishing on that hot sunny afternoon.  Crafting different types of lures or using different types of bait to attract different types of fish would be cool.  Fishing could also be dependent on the time of day and the weather.9.	Climbing trees to get away from predators when all you have is a rock in your hand to defend yourself.  The only problem with this type of defence is that the predator will not go away and you will eventually starve to death sitting in the tree, unless you can eat the tree leaves. Picture the scene from the Movie ‘Quest for Fire’.10.	Throw rocks, especially at tigers and the forest children. 11.	Pets, a dog like creature, horse or riding type creature.12.	Other wildlife critters to hunt or to just watch, such as ungulates, birds and predator type creatures.13.	Different mystical biome creatures, one for each type of biome.14.	More world ambient sounds, such as a hooting owl in the haunted forest biome, howling critters when the moon rises, etc.15.	Weather systems such as rain, snow, thunder storms, tornados, etc.16.	More uses for critter hides other than leather strips.17.	Crafting implements of destruction such as a trebuchet or canon to silent that noisy forest child, just kidding.In closing, all I can say about TUG is that it is an awesome game so far and has the potential of being one of the best open world sandbox survival games presently being developed.  All the best to the developers at Nerd Kingdom and keep up the great work.

Early Access Review
								TUG or The Un-named Game is a Survival/Crafting game. You play as a Seed. Seeds have a blue gem embedded in the back of their left hand and are genderless. This later will be an important part of the game. In TUG you can craft an assortment of different items to aid you in everything from farming to combat and even using alchemy and magic.Currently you have two status bars, Health and Energy. Doing various tasks will use up your energy and require you to eat to refill it. Health is lowered by creatures that attack you or eating poisen mushrooms.You have the ability to sprint, although not unlimited. Sprinting lasts longer in TUG than most other games and the Sprint Meter refills at a very decent rate.You can use such items as wood chips, mushrooms and bone meal among others, to brew potions.The growth potion will allow you to grow crops faster and even turn a baby animal into an adult. (Both of these take time).You can currently breed goats and cats and even breed them together to get the awesome cogat!TUG features the unique ability for the character to age, get stronger, faster and even fatter. This is in the very early stages and needs more time before it is finished.One of the more recent updates has improved biome generation greatly. Biomes feel real and authentic. There is a large assortment of plant life and natural resources. The game is decently optimized but is lack luster in some areas. You may experience lag spikes or a constant low fps unless you have a decent computer. The devs are working on this and will hopefully have TUG ready for a wider range of computers soon.Sound effects and graphics are fairly good and offers a unique experience. The higher the settings you can use, the better overall experience you'll have playing.Currently TUG offers stone age to the bronze age but lacks in content. You'll find it hard to keep going after 15 hours or so, some never make it that far while others make it hundreds of hours.I recommend purchasing on sale around $10 until more content and optimizations go into the game. Don't get me wrong, I like this game. I would even say I love it but if I'm going to be honest I have to tell both sides.Watch some videos, check out some reviews and heck, even try purchasing the game and playing for an hour. Steam will refund no questions asked if you've not had the game longer than 14 days or played more than 2 hours.If you're not comitted to playing an early access game with an prototype level of content and willing to deal with lost saves and bugs, I'd wait. Early Access after all is about helping guide the game to the finish line.I'd rate the following:Concept 10/10Graphics 7/10SFX 6/10Content to Price Ratio 4/10

Early Access Review
Key supplied by developer for review.======================================The Untitled Game Read on for the full review!======================================TL;DR:TUG is a good game with a lot of potential, but there's not quite enough to do yet. The devs are good, transparent and working hard. If you like supporting a worthwhile Early Access game, give this one a buy!======================================Pros+Graphics: Good mix of cartoonish and realistic.+Gameplay: Sparse but good, with tons of crafting recipes!+Audio: Just enough sounds to be effective.+Workflow: Intuitive crafting/inventory management.Cons-Gameplay: Only so much to do currently.-Gameplay: Needs more things to hunt/enemies!-Audio: Some actions are missing sounds.Neutral+/- Crafting/inventory management can take some adjustment.+/- It may not exactly be obvious how to do things at first.======================================Introduction:TUG is one among many survival sandbox games. It features a fantasy setting and charming, cute, simple-yet-pretty graphics. In TUG, like many sandboxes, you will have to work your way through the tech tree from the ground up. TUG also has an amazingly upfront dev team whose main concern is their game and consumer. So what's it like?Gameplay:The first time you start TUG you may be alarmed by the long load time, but don't worry, only the first will take that long. When you get into the game, you may find yourself wondering what to do or how to do it. A quick bit of information gathering will fix that. The first thing you will want to do in TUG is gather objects for tools. To do this you have to tear down a sapling or small tree, leaving you with a wood handle. At this point you will need a properly shaped rock and some vines. Once you find said properly shaped rock laying around (usually near other, larger rocks) and some vines (easy to spot and abundant) you can put them all on the ground together and hit G to craft your first primitive tool!Hooray! That wasn't so bad, was it? From here on out your imagination is the limit.TUG, unlike many sandboxes, features a beautiful voxel terrain editor, allowing you to shape the earth pretty much however you see fit. Doing so is a quick and easy process, as you can use virtually any primitive tool. Filling the terrain in with wood or stone, however, is not nearly as quick. So for those of you who hate seeing servers on survival sandbox games where there are tons of halfbuilt or poorly built structures you can rest easy. You can also rest easy in knowing that your buildings will take work and will be an accomplishment.This leads to a startling revelation: building is fun. building with friends is more fun. Aside from building, crafting, hunting, and farming, there isn't too much to do in the game's current state-but what is there is fun, with more on the way. There is, however, an absolutely EXTENSIVE amount of things to craft, so if you're into making things, you're in the right place.Graphics:The graphics in TUG are a treat. Again I will state that they are strangely pretty, considering their simplistic and cute nature. You will find that there are lush biomes filled with dense foliage, as many types of trees as you could ever want, and various bioluminescent plants and resources scattered about. The colors are at times muted, and almost always earthy, but that won't stop you from finding sand or snowswept locales. As a man that appreciates variety, I was very pleased with both the amount and the look of the biomes available in TUG. Aside from biomes I want to take a moment to talk about the look of buildings. In TUG, when you place a wood block next to a cobblestone block, they will blend together, and this can make for both some pretty--and pretty interesting--ideas and aesthetics.The presence of fog, various cloud types, sky colors, moon and sun, darkness, etc. make for an overall pleasing and immersive graphical experience that I'm sure you'll enjoy!Audio:The audio in TUG is also a treat, albeit a sparse one, but this is a good thing. In a sandbox you don't want obnoxious music distracting you from you building, fighting, hunting, crafting. You want relaxing music with good atmospheric sounds, and audio cues that would be distinct a mile apart, and in TUG, you have that. The audio stays in the background until it needs to be in the foreground, and I appreciate that so much. While many games try to pull on your heartstrings too much with music and sound, TUG manages to make you feel things by playing the right sound at the right time. The sounds that are there serve their purposes well, although more sounds would be nice, for example, when swinging a weapon.Conclusion:TUG is a great sandbox with a lot of potential. It already has solid building mechanics and tons of crafting recipes. If you are okay with supporting a vision, give it a buy!======================================If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

Early Access Review
								I bought into TUG during its Kickstarter campaign back in May 2013. It honestly sounded awesome at the time. The campaign pitched a "multiplayer open-world sandbox-RPG using new technology and social sciences to directly involve players in the game’s design." I thought wow that sounds like it could be something special! Fast forward more than 3 years later, and very little progress has been made. In January 2016 the developers sent out a message to backers explaining how they were scrapping the DX11 engine they had been working on and were now working towards moving over to OpenGL, further explaining that there would be no more game updates for at least around 12 months. That means we’ll be (hopefully) seeing the next engine update sometime around early 2017, in an early alpha stage, four years after the Kickstarter ended. In the same January ’16 update the developers also pitched the idea of making TUG a Free to Play 'game', with monetisation of user mods. TUG would no longer be a complete game in itself, but rather a base platform that others could make content mods for, and sell to other users.  That to me sounds completely terrible, and it is definitely not something I would have had anything to do with if I had known that's where things were possibly headed. Now to be fair the decisions of going Free to Play with monetised mods has still yet to be made, but throwing out the suggestion like that and announcing no decision will be made for a full year was quite honestly a terrible way to handle things. In the 8 months since that announcement, the community has all but disappeared (at least the current players on Steam), reviews have gone to hell, and community confusion has most definitely set in. Not a great situation for any game to be in. I’ll be keeping an eye on the games progress and will update this review accordingly, but at this stage I’ve just about lost hope that TUG will be developed through to completion and to a state that matches what was originally promised to early backers.  I have a feeling that updates and communication will continue to slow down, to a point where development is quietly cancelled. Time will tell though and I would love to be proven wrong.

								I would like to state right off the bat, that I do not hate this game at all. I was actually going to purchase a copy of the game for my wife today to play it together, found out it had been taken off the store, and read the AMA and related info.This is a complicated game to review, but I felt I would share my thoughts so far. This game has has a lot of heart and love put into it so far, it's very obvious when playing it. It has a very immersive feel as well, via placing objects on the ground, instead of storing hordes of trash in numerous boxes. The feeling of digging out a mine, and having to dump the rock and dirt out the hole, is simple, but adds to that immersion. I also love the sound and effects at night time; That eerie wind and ambience is just mind blowing. Every update to this game, I update and play, as they had been adding tons of unique content. However, I have to put emphasis on "had." They did work on new biome generation and terrain generation as of last year, which was a big task to do, but there wasn't much else added in. They had a good reputation for releasing small, but potent updates to the game frequently, and highlighting them on their youtube channel, which I would reccomend following if you're at all interested in the game. The youtube channel itself describes what I'm talking about. A lof of the updates come slower than the last, and several of the "in the works" projects being worked on never saw the light of day.  The last major update involved adding a crafting journal, which was great, but those changes were far too small in the scope of what was supposed to be there. It was disappointing to constantly wait to see changes to this game, only to try it out again in a few months, and being disappointed, or bored after a couple hours. It just feels too "barren" for a game that has been in EA this long.I felt like the game had an amazing direction, of molding your "seed" and it's appearance, which reminded me of Fable in a way. This awesome feeling of exploring a survival world, with less focus  on survival, and more on exploring and progression in a sense and the players making their own "game" in a sense, by offering a diverse solid universe. It seems, and I may be wrong, that they focus more and more on the "pvp" community and pvp in general, rather than coop survival, which seemed like the original spirit of the game. This news comes on the heels of their announcment to make the game F2P, and nothing good rarely comes from a F2P model. While I have no doubt that they will do their best to make it a fair F2P model, if that is the route they choose, it doesn't seem like an idea that makes a whole ton of sense to me.That being said, the devs are a great team of people, and I have a huge amount of respect for their vision for this game, and have given it nothing but praise up until this point. They are very active in discussions about it, and interacting with the community.I still have the best hopes for this game, and look forward to the final product. I still am in love with that original trailer, and what I imagined it could be. Even in it's current form, it is a good game, to be perfectly fair. In some senses, I don't feel the devs give themselves enough credit, and are too worried about failing. We just need to see content that changes the game, and adds to it drastically. More pets, more mounts, more weapons and armors, more enemies, boss monsters, and places to explore and learn more about the interesting story they've put behind this game. It should also go without mention to how amazing the art is for TUG.The end note I guess is, that it's great they want to work in a new engine for the game, in a way. But it's a risky move, as we've seen what can happen with games like DayZ, wanting to 'redo' the entire game to make it better. I will still check out the updates from time to time, but it's sad to see that they almost seem to be damaging the game by taking it off the market, instead of trying to promote it more. I know these devs are a small team, and very talented, with a work load far above their numbers, but this just seems like a baffling move. I only wanted to write this because I had a lot of hope for this game. I wasn't a KS backer, but I did buy into EA very shortly after it came out on Steam.TL;DR Wait until the finished product comes out, and see what they have. (Not that you have a choice now, at least for a year.) If things change for the better, and there's actually content that keeps me invested, my review would change to a positive in a second.

Early Access Review
ATTENTION: The review below was last updated on January 12, 2015 and is sorely outdated.  I have not given further attention to this game and cannot update the review.  I'm avoiding deleting this review for the sake of maintaining a historical perspective, but to be fair to the game and the developer, please skip this review and see something more recent.While TUG seems to have some good ideas, I cannot recommend it at this point.  It shows promise and may be worth taking a look at later on in development.Building  There really isn't a whole lot to do at this point.  You can build, though there doesn't seem to be a wide range of blocks available just yet.    Also, while the texture blending on placed blocks is very nice in most cases, I'm not sure how suitable it is when building a house (ex: grass blending with wood or wood blending with cobblestone wall).  In my opinion, some of the tools should work a little bit faster.  Ex: digging up an area can be long and tedious. HuntingI've only seen two different sorts of mob so far, though there's supposed to be a third (some manner of predatory cat?).  The giggles/growls of the little mushroom imp are irritating.Crafting  IMPORTANT: Software should almost never make choices for the user.  In order to craft, we must throw our ingredients on the ground and press G.  If the ingredients match any recipe, the item will be crafted.  If the ingredients match multiple recipes, a random item will be crafted. No!  Just, no!  Take an example where I want to build two spears.  I gather two shafts, two spear heads, and some vines, toss them on the floor, and hit G.  Oops... I forgot that the vine wall takes two shafts and some vines... Instead, when there are multiple recipes available, pop up a small dialog which lists the available options.  For any recipe that is unknown to the player (ie: player has never crafted it), provide the option with an "Unknown Recipe" label.  I'm a little worried that the current crafting implementation will result in a glut of crafting components.  Compare to Minecraft where a grid defines the resulting item.  Without the grid (or without the option above), we need to have specific items in order to decide what the recipe will result in as can be seen with the multiple tool heads that are required right now (axe, pick, hammer, sword).  With a grid or the above method, we could simplify the recipe to "a handle + a stone".  This means players need less storage space (ie: chests).  Items which are not implemented probably should have their recipe disabled.  I was disappointed to craft the leaf backpack and find that it does nothing.  I was about to craft a chest and read that it wasn't implemented either.Inventory/Hotbar-thing  I find the inventory to be woefully small, but I understand that the character we're playing is a child with a tiny backpack.  This could possibly be mitigated by bumping up stack sizes for some things (ie: I believe wooden shafts have a stack size of 2...?  That seems fairly low)  I imagine those spaces at the bottom are some sort of hotbar, so I was frustrated to find that items get shuffled around and don't just stay put.  In my mind, if I set items in a specific order in my hotbar, they should always be in that order.Side-note/Request: I find the sound effect that gets played when the "TUG" splash is displayed during game load to be a little bit on the louder side.  Would be nice if that could get toned down a bit or follow configured volume settings.

There's a creature in the game in which is very creepy and can scare the pants off of anyone with their screams (I know this because it takes a lot to scare me even slightly), but they seem to be completely harmless. There isn't too much content yet to keep a person busy for a long time like other similar games which are further in development obviously, but there is enough to see and do to keep a person busy for about 10 hours or more depending on play style, and I'm sure as this very young game develops further, we'll see a lot more content making the game all that much better giving us hundreds more hours of content. There's plenty of glitches and occasional crashes here and there as well as the potential to corrupt the save file (unlikely though it did happen to me once while I suicided off a mountain clipping through the terrain upon death and spawning inside the terrain falling and dying again). The crashes are more than tolerable because the game automatically saves all the time and you can also manually save after doing something if you're nervous of a crash, though I kind of wish it had multi save files in case it corrupted itself again.One thing I will say is you WILL get permanently lost a lot while exploring because there is no compass or map and the foliage and terrain is very thick and difficult to see at a decent range while in the forest. I recommend crafting a bed asap and build towers everywhere around your base to help prevent yourself from getting lost (though you'll likely still get lost anyways if your base is in the forest, lol). The best place to build a base would probably be at the edge of a forest biome near another biome so you have that edge to follow and isn't hidden inside the forest but is near the forest so you can collect all the trees needed.I paid the full $11 for this game and I have zero regrets so far. The direction the game is going looks great so far, next big update potentially being multiplayer support? The only thing I can suggest is for ppl to research a little more into it before buying so that they're not surprised by how early in development the game is in.Will update this review as I play it more. Current review is based off of v0.6.5

								After playing for a few hours I think I'm ready to write this review.    First thing to take note of is that it's in early alpha, this means that everything could change. Another thing is that there WILL be glitches and crashes that you WILL experience throughout your playthrough. This game dips a bit into the minecraft environment but then goes into its own world.     Now let's talk about the actual game. When you first spawn in I had to look at the wiki. I had NO clue on how to get started, though once I found out what I was supposed to do I began to build up my resources. After getting mauled by Sabertooth Tigers I finally found my new home. At this point I was scared, always watching my back in case another Sabertooth Tiger was ready to pounce on me. Then above all that, I had little girls laughing at me, that's freakin' creepy man. To sum that up, I was REALLY feeling the intensity of the game, When I first heard the cave sounds I booked it out of there and never went back.     The crafting is actually a really nice idea, the fact that you're actually crafting on the ground, on flat rocks and then on workbenches (depending on the item your crafting) makes it more realistic. Another thing is that when you're actually looking at the recipe you can actually SEE how the cobination of these things will make the item you'll be crafting.    The building in the game is quite easy to do, the ability to see where a item will be placing is also a nice little extra for building. The blocks meld together which gives it a nice natural feel to your builds. Remember: If you have the materials, you can build anything you want.   Food is essential to survive, we all know that right? TUG allows players to plant crops varrying from pumpkins, gourds to cherry trees. Another thing you can eat is meat from goats. That’s all the food for now but I’m sure they’ll be adding lots more in the future.   The graphics are fine for the stage of development it’s in. Don’t expect some amazing top notch graphics from TUG, if you do that you have a high chance of being disapointed. Though, again this is in Early Alpha so everything COULD change. There’s some things they’re working on like better terrain generation, alchemy, and different things of the sort. Multiplayer will also help the game incredibly, once you bring in multiplayer the people who already have the game create a chain reaction. Player -) Friend -) Another Friend -) Another Friend -) ANOTHER FRIEND and so on.   Overall, I say buy it while it’s cheap.You get a game with a lot of potential and all of its updates for only $10 Once this game gets more and more features I can see it being sold for around $30-$45 easily.

								After playing for a few hours I think I'm ready to write this review.    First thing to take note of is that it's in early alpha, this means that everything could change. Another thing is that there WILL be glitches and crashes that you WILL experience throughout your playthrough. This game dips a bit into the minecraft environment but then goes into its own world.     Now let's talk about the actual game. When you first spawn in I had to look at the wiki. I had NO clue on how to get started, though once I found out what I was supposed to do I began to build up my resources. After getting mauled by Sabertooth Tigers I finally found my new home. At this point I was scared, always watching my back in case another Sabertooth Tiger was ready to pounce on me. Then above all that, I had little girls laughing at me, that's freakin' creepy man. To sum that up, I was REALLY feeling the intensity of the game, When I first heard the cave sounds I booked it out of there and never went back.     The crafting is actually a really nice idea, the fact that you're actually crafting on the ground, on flat rocks and then on workbenches (depending on the item your crafting) makes it more realistic. Another thing is that when you're actually looking at the recipe you can actually SEE how the cobination of these things will make the item you'll be crafting.    The building in the game is quite easy to do, the ability to see where a item will be placing is also a nice little extra for building. The blocks meld together which gives it a nice natural feel to your builds. Remember: If you have the materials, you can build anything you want.   Food is essential to survive, we all know that right? TUG allows players to plant crops varrying from pumpkins, gourds to cherry trees. Another thing you can eat is meat from goats. That’s all the food for now but I’m sure they’ll be adding lots more in the future.   The graphics are fine for the stage of development it’s in. Don’t expect some amazing top notch graphics from TUG, if you do that you have a high chance of being disapointed. Though, again this is in Early Alpha so everything COULD change. There’s some things they’re working on like better terrain generation, alchemy, and different things of the sort. Multiplayer will also help the game incredibly, once you bring in multiplayer the people who already have the game create a chain reaction. Player -) Friend -) Another Friend -) Another Friend -) ANOTHER FRIEND and so on.   Overall, I say buy it while it’s cheap.You get a game with a lot of potential and all of its updates for only $10 Once this game gets more and more features I can see it being sold for around $30-$45 easily.

Early Access Review
								TL;DR version: Incomplete - can be played but feels unfinished, and falls far short of the Kickstarter plans. Company has changed funding systems a couple of times and it's doubtful they'll finish the game. PR announcements are very much "please be patient" without stating any specific goals or timelines.I wanted so much to love this game. I backed it on Kickstarter because of the charming concept video, noted the high hardware requirements (at the time) and made sure, over a year later, that when I bought a new laptop, it had the specs to run TUG. A few months after that, I tracked down my invite key (everyone who'd paid for access, even beta or later, got an alpha access key) and sorted out how to connect through Steam and use the regularly-updated dev version, and... bleh.Not only are the features I waited for not here, not only does it look like the features I'd love to see won't be included (music, for one), the company is so fraught with changes that it doesn't look like the game will ever be functional as originally advertised.It's playable now. It's enjoyable now, if you like a particular style of explore-and-build, which I mostly do. Crafting is "unique," which is a euphemism for "we decided to ignore a couple decades' worth of game development and come up with a system that's entirely non-intuitive and also prone to mistakes." (To craft: you place items on the ground, next to each other, and press "G".) But it's woefully incomplete, and there's no evidence that will ever change; the dev team doesn't seem to have a clear plan, even if they had funding, which is shaky. What's missing:* Ladders - a way to change height without elaborate spiral staircases* Carts - a way to haul stuff other than in a very limited backpack* Hosted multiplayer - Nerd Kingdom originally planned to host "Survival" (PVP anything goes) and "Adventure" (which most players seem to think means "easy mode") servers; while multiplayer is now possible, there are no dedicated servers* About half the creatures mentioned in the Kickstarter (to be fair, there were fewer a year ago; progress is being made here)* Renewable resources - once you've grabbed the axe rocks and cut down wood trees from your local area, they're gone, meaning you really can't build sustainable communities - you have to keep traveling farther for basic supplies* Compass, or any other reasonable way to find "home" once it's not visible* Writing, or any other way to leave messages for yourself or other players* Several types of envronmental blocks and building supplies that are probably planned - lava, water, cloth, * Many kinds of tools* Golems (from the kickstarter), other NPCs, deitiesWhen (if?) TUG starts again - it's unavailable for purchase as I write this, which is not a good sign for its long-term success - I recommend checking recent reviews to find out if it's become viable.

Early Access Review
								Should you buy TUG alpha version 0.8.5? It depends:Do you want to be able to spend a few hours in a row playing a game the way you're used to? If so, DO NOT buy TUG during the Alpha stage of Early Access. You will be disappointed at the lack of content and features. Do you expect a polished and optimized engine? Don't buy TUG yet, it's just not that far along. On the other hand, do you want to talk with the developers about how things might work before they're added? Do you wonder whether people play games differently when game mechanics change? Do you just like discussing what you love about gaming? Then maybe you'll enjoy owning TUG alpha. (I'm having a blast!) Don't get me wrong, you will be able to play around in TUG. You can spend a few hours fighting friends, playing around with what harvesting and crafting is there, or building a huge base in creative mode. You can mod many aspects of the game, make fan objects, art. or textures, put up YouTube tutorials, and watch the occasional livestreams. But as of this writing, much of the gameplay just isn't there yet. That is just the way Alphas work. Early access development is pretty active: updates don't happen frequently, but every new release includes large changes, and several brand new types of gameplay. (Version 0.8.5 added the first version of aging and body morphing, completely revamped how the sky looks and works, and added some new clothing and building material recipes.)So, before you buy, check out the game forums here[forum.nerdkingdom.com], watch TUG's In The Works videos, read through the kickstarter update posts here. Do the features currently in place sound fun? Are you inspired by the vision and possibilities? Are you itching to talk about the ways you love to play? Then decide whether it's too early to pay for.

								The best sandbox-survival game I've played. I typically don't like sandbox-survival games, but after watching the videos and seeing its potential, I decided to give it a go. I love it! Like other sandbox games, it focuses on crafting your own materials and hunting wild animals (such as tigers and goats) for resources. The difference, and uniqueness with TUG is a higher focus on who you are as a Seedling, that can grow, change, and morph based on what you eat, how much you craft, etc. You can tame cubs, raise them, breed them, and eventually ride them (I hope, given that there's a saddle in game). It's easy to build your own shelter, make farmland and grow your own plants, etc etc.A lot of negative reviews have low play time and state that it's "hard" to figure out. Well, yes, it's an alpha game. If you're having trouble getting going, check out the TUG Crafting Guide in the Community Hub.I would recommend it to everyone, really. This game has so much potential, and it's a lot of fun!

								So far, this is a fun and interesting game. It is meant to be played with...or against friends...and it does have a steep, and I really do mean steep learning curve. Getting started and crafting useful items is your first main challenge. Crafting in this game is not done on a grid as in most survival/crafting games... instead, you lay the items you want to try combining on a flat surface such as a rock slab and press G on the crafting surface. If the items combine to make something, you will see a crafting bar and then the resulting item afterwards. Take my word on this however...play around and figure out what to combine to make what on your own, don't cheat and look up the crafting recipes. The sense of acomplishment from discovering what makes what is part of the fun. This game has a way of making you feel like a cave man (or woman) discovering the basics of survival. The game is rough around the edges in the current state but this is also a very early build of the game...so keep that in mind. I can see this being a fun one to play with friends, seeing who is the ultimate survivor. :)

Early Access Review
								I haven't played much of this game yet, but from what I have seen, I'm impressed.  I've played diffrent RPG and crafting games before and quite frankly I'm not easily impressed.  (This is after all the only review I have ever written for a game or intend to write.)  I will therefore lay out what will most likely be a rather long dissertation on a deserving game in blocks that can be digested at will in this format:Things I didn't like (short list and always take the bad news first)Things I liked (much longer list)Things I would like to see integrated.  (Based on researching the game wiki and the discussions I've seen on the game's direction.)Things I didn't like:Not much.  Most of these have been brought up by other people, please accept this as my own take and as purely constructive criticism.Game Speed: I use a fairly good computer, but this is the first game I've had serious latency and fps issues with.  I read up on the game and how to mitigate some of this but it is still somewhat of a system resource hog.  I've read other articles where this was brought up and I also read that this is something that may be improving as the game is refined.  It is my sincere hope that this is the case because it was the only thing the prevented me from becoming addicted and having several times more hours devoted to this game than what I have.Animal AI: Likewise something that was brought up in different review and I agree.  In my case I kept looking around for the goats I could hear that kept getting worse and found a ditch close to my base camp where they kept falling in and the number of them kept growing.  I assume this had something to do with spawn behavior, but for now I just promised myself to return later to cash in on easily obtained goat meat as necessary.Things I liked:Two size blocks:  I believe this is an improvement over Minecraft.  Don't get me wrong, I love Minecraft for what it is, but this strikes me as the next logical advancement.  More complex shapes, better environment texture, all of this benefits from a larger number of building blocks available.  I have seen the type of complex mechanisms offered by games like Landmark, and I believe that this is overly involved.  A good balance similar to what is seen in Space Engineers is more desirable to me.  Possible areas for improvement would include slanted blocks so a roof can have an honest slope instead of a stair step effect.  I'm working on a thatch roof hut so it would look better that way.Crafting Component and Crafting Surface Interface:  I will admit that at first I found this to be a bit cumbersome as I was first learning the game.  Admittedly I jumped straight in without doing that much research or watching many videos.  After I got used to it though I quickly fell in love with the quasi-realism.  The system lends itself well to using the same components in different recipes based on what work surface is being used or what tool you are holding.  It can be frustrating, but in the long run rewarding.  I could almost see a realistic NPC trainer scenario where a player coul learn a recipe by watching an NPC or other player laying out the components on the correct surface and equipping the appropriate tool.Item Placement:  I have played Skyrim and one of the most frustrating parts of that game was the item placement mode that didn't give you much control over the items your were placing.  This game has definitely improved in that function.  Instead of containers that give you a UI panel to add and remove from similar to an inventory screen, I found myself actually making "real world" storage solutions.  My hut had wooden beam rafters where I stored my spears, poles, etc. for easy storage and retrieval.  My garden had a "compost heap" next to it where extra leaves, seeds, and other unused items went.  I am anxious to experiment with handles that I might be able to create a rack down the wall for my spears.Visual Appearance:  This game is a promising blend of something like Skyrim and Minecraft,  The graphics are beautiful and I can't wait to explore other biomes just as soon as I'm certain I won't get lost.  The realism of the gaming experience because of the graphics combined with real life issues like getting lost in the wild give the game a very high immersion level.Technology Level:  Where can I begin about the technology level?  Obviously, at the beginning, just like with the technology of the characters.  The opportunities for development with this game bogle the mind.  In its current state at simple bronze age technology there are a fair amount of recipes available that could be made and make a game comparable to Minecraft.  As technology levels increase, the addition of new work centers and recipes only serve to give the game additional depth.  The idea of going from Stone Age to Space Age and beyond seems enticing, but I am going to wait and see what transpires here.  It would also be similarly interesting to see higher and higher levels of magical complexity.  Rituals, better/more powerful potions, spells, and enchantments could advance with technology level as well.  This game concept has me excited.Things I would like to see integrated:After reading the section of the wiki on this game and seeing the yet to be introduced game elements that are still in process I wanted to be sure to add in the things that I as a gamer value and would like to see.  On the off chance that a developer might actually read this review, please take as focus group data if nothing else.Family/Tribe Generation: One of the somewhat disappointing aspects of Skyrim and Minecraft are the social interactions with the world.  This does not necessarily entail an in depth quest and/or dialogue engine like Warcraft (Long Live CLan Arandel!) or some of the dating simulators out there.  I was looking at the 'aging' concept presented in the wiki and was hoping that we would see something that might actually allow the character to spawn progeny.  Nothing perverted mind you, but if there were a spell called 'mating ritual' you could complete near a NPC of the oppostie gender that would generate or spawn an aging offspring from toddler up to adult would be most refreshing.  The villager breeding mechanic found in Minecraft comes to mind, but the villagers leave something ot be desired in that game.  I see self generated quests as players watch a wandering monster kill a favorite offspring and then tracking the monster (or PvP player) down for revenge.NPC generation:  I saw the article on totems that could have little podlings carrying out tasks for the character and I thought that this would be rather novel.  I like this concept and I hope it gets expanded into the ability to create a village of NPCs either through breeding (as above), conjuration, or perhaps even rescuing the people from AI Monsters.  The usefulness of these characters couold range from merely asthetic value to contributing members of a community.  I would go into more detail, but I'm running out of room in the review.Baskets:  Stone Age containers.  I don't mind chests, but the open air basket that holds stuff would be a nice change.  As long as they are stationary and don't fly everywhere like they do in Skyrim.Clothing:  The most customizable part of a character.  The Sims makes a fortune off of people that go onto their online store looking for new outfits for their Sims.  I think that level of variety is a bit overblown, but when playing Warcarft and all the max level characters look the same it gets kind of old.  There are several color dye possibilities with the mushrooms so a simple color shift might be enough.  I simply think that more than just leather armor should be capable of being dyed and the clothing options should change with technology level.More work stations.  Leatherworking, tailoring, jewelry, etc.  The more the merrier.  Crap out of room.  Later!

Early Access Review
								What can i say about this game; It has the likeness of minecraft and rust, plain and simple, so im going to use minecraft/rust as an indirect comparison.Remember before you even think about buying this game that it is early alpha and the developers aka nerdkingdom do not to my knowledge have any releases of any games under their belt, they are backed and supported by feedthebeast so based on this im giving them a moderate to low risk of getting a game thats not finished and thrown together.Disclaimer;As your reading this you may think this game is not for you or maybe im giving it a negative review in writing but recommending it anyway. My review is based on the current state of the game and will likely not reflect some if not all of the finished product and will only probably be relevent for the near future of the games development.(This is quite a long review so if you cant be bothered reading on ive included a overview at the bottom)Gameplay;You play as what i would describe as an elvin creature who has been dumped on a proceeduraly generated world (using the famous world seed system) there are numberous different resourses available to you and a crafting tech tree that can be progressed up. At the moment it is fairly easy to survive the "energy" (food meter) is easy to fill and once you have found an apple or orange tree you will never go hungry again. Additionally the AI is clunky and stupid, the only time your in trouble from them is in wide open spaces as they like to run into walls wherre you can stand just out of range and kill them. Additionally your own navigation is hindered by just 1 block height (explains the clunky ai) meaning getting out of your mine takes a lot of jumping and a bit of patience (Yes minecraft does this too but you dont slip back down again)Mining;Most of your resources for level 1 tech tree and any basic building material can be found lying around across the entire map, but the tools currently are unbalanced with the pickaxe and the hammer doing the job to quickly and of course the shovel doing the job to slowly and higher level tech tree ores are very rare and hard to find a few balancing issues then here but that particular feature is fresh out of the box.Building;The building aspect of this game definately needs some work and you wont be building mega structures just yet as block placement i find is a little bit fiddely, but on the bright side anything you build does come together nicely with the textures all blending seemlessly together.Mod Support;Yes im giving this its own section because it remarkable at how easily modded this game is in fact it pretty much has about the same or better mod support than a lot of games out there. For an early alpha thats impressive.You wont see that many mods yet but i believe they will come strong and fast as just looking at the way mods are imported into the game it seems remarkably too good to be true.Graphics;Not much to say here compared to rust and minecraft I would say they are miles better.Overview;If you like minecraft or rust and want to support a game that has soo much potential to be better than both of them then for $9.99 or £6.00ish  you really are not risking a lot of money by buying early alpha and with the developers letting us know the price is due to rise as more features are imported into the game, it really is a great time to invest in this game.I look at the review above and think to myself it really looks quite negative but trust me providing you remember that it is an alpha you wont care about that. With multiplayer support on its way im looking forward to loading this game backup again once the multiplayer support is added.For those of you interested in a polished off game with as many features as minecraft, alls i have to say is wait for a later beta or final release.

Early Access Review
								Thanks to various bug fixes, I can now change my solid "no" vote to a very cautious "yes" vote. Tug is an ambitious project that manages to bring enough to the table that's different to not be immediately written off as "just another minecraft style game".The graphics are smooth and appealing, what little sound there is in the game thus far is very effective, and the crafting system is unique and sufficient once you get the hang of it. Emphasis on "once you get the hang of it", as that's one of the biggest reasons I'm saying this is a good game instead of an outstandingly great one.The way that TUG is currently set up, when you start out the game they drop you in your world, pants or not, with no instructions what so ever. If you aren't a hardened vet in the genre, you'd better pull up a guide online and make notes, because TUG tells you absolutely nothing in-game. You might figure out how to survive and make some basic tools and so forth on your own with enough trial and error, but some players will give up long before they reach the point where TUG starts to shine because of the complex and unexplained nature of the game's mechanics. That's not the only issue TUG has, but it's still early access so some bugs and issues are bound to happen. It can be difficult to get things like beds to sit flat on your floor instead of lodged halfway through your character, sometimes items will vanish when you leave the room (such as beds) or will cease to be when you merely meant to drop them, for example. If you know what you're doing, these issues are rarely a game breaking experience, but it can detract from your ability to stay immersed and having fun.The act of mining in TUG is similar in nature to how it is in Minecraft, but like a lot of things, it feels more organic. I never thought I'd be looking back at the tunnel I'd just dug and thinking "Damn that's a pretty tunnel", but digging ends up being one of the most enjoyable parts of the game because of how fluid and unstilted the process becomes. Overall, TUG accomplishes what it sets out to do. It's enjoyable, not too difficult, and pretty to look at. If you've played Minecraft and are looking for something that's a little less precise and a little more organic in both look and feel, watch some videos of TUG and then give it a try. You could do a lot worse with your money on here these days.

								I have played this game for a very long time off and on, I have probably clocked more than 50 hours in this game through the launcher plus what I already have clocked through Steam.  With that said this game has come a long way from its early alpha stages.  If you are a fan of games like Minecraft, Rust, Stranded Deep, etc... then you will be a huge fan of this game.  Crafting is really well done, in the world, not in a crafting window.  The worlds are procedurally generated and there are numerous biomes that offer their own set of challenges.  It has multiplayer support, and an infinite degree of building options.  You can build a house, a cave, a mansion, a castle, the possibilities are limitless.The survival aspects are pretty fun too, food is your most valuable resource and you will die without it.  It can be abundant enough to let you have fun, but also can be elusive enough that you are challenged by it in some biomes.  The Dev team really cares about their game and product and are very active on their forums and here on Steam.  I can not give this game enough thumbs up. Early Access Review
								TLDR: Really cool and has potential but still evident that it is early access.Very enjoyable if a little 'unfinished'. Tug is still in progress (something the devs are very clear about) and because of this the world is still slightly deserted, there isn't that much one can do in game and there are a large number of bugs. But, even at this early stage it is still completely playable. The graphics are breathtaking, I may not be a fount of experience in regards to games and their quality but I have seen my fair share and TUG is definitely one of the better ones. The crafting system is unique and not overly complex, even if some of the recipes aren't always intuitive.Nerd Kingdom has a distinct and clear vision of the general direction in which they want their game to go and I am sitting on the edge of my seat in anticipation. While the idea of a procedurally generated world with unique quests, events, landforms NPCs, etc. may not be exactly new, their plan for a dynamic playable character that adapts according to what the player does with said character is revolutionary (that's what I believe in any case) and I am looking forward to the completion and implementation of this feature. I can appreciate the planning that was put into this game as well as Nerd Kingdom and its devs consideration in regard to the users/players and what they want (this is evident in the name of the game).The style and approach possessed by this game and its creators is remarkable. Unfortunately there is a downside: the game is very demanding in regards to processing, it is very laggy with medium-high graphics’ settings with reasonably capable computer stats (although if you look at how the world is generated/looks it is understandable if regrettable).In the world of procedurally generated voxel worlds TUG, is a breath of fresh air in a smog of boring Minecraft remakes, rehashes and reskins. The game is still incomplete and I wouldn't suggest you buy it if you are looking for a game that you will play for hundreds of hours without running out of things to do. I do suggest however that you support the developers of TUG, they are doing something amazing. From my limited knowledge of game development it appears as if they have injected an astronomical amount of energy into the creation of this game by producing their own game engine and doing things in a new and untested way. I would just like to say that I appreciate their hard work and consideration.

								For an Early Access game I can kinda recommend it, I'm really on fence between recommending and not. I mostly support it because of the developer's philosophy.Pro-* Developers who promise to shape TUG based on player's actions and feedback. imo, this is way better then your run-of-mill arrogant know-it-all developer.* Designed from the ground up to be modded. This is a primary goal for developers while making TUG.* I like TUG's art style.con-* TUG seems to be in perpetual early access.* Very poorly optimized as of the DX11 version. Maybe the new OpenGL version will be better. My budget computer (AMD FX 4100, Geforce GT 610, 16GB) can only run it with the lowest possible settings and I still get choppy game play.* The crafting diversity is tiny. Within maybe a day you can craft all the items there are to make. After that it's about building creative structures.* The PvE content is tiny (hunting, fighting, raiding). The forest, fauna, and earth types are diverse. Although, the creatures that populate these lands are few in type and in number. I've only seen goat, cat, and bull. Of these few types I'd spend at least 15 minuets wandering around looking for them. There is lots of potential to build things but very little if you want to hunt and fight.

								UPDATE 07/14/16: Just read their last announcement here. I hate F2P games to the bones. Looks like another dev abandoning their game. If you want to know how to craft something, either you just try stuff out until something pops out or you got onto the web to look up the crafting recipes, which is what I did, but why can't there be a small guide (like in The Forest for example) that tells me what I need to craft. doesn't have to autocraft from within the guide, just a simple info book of what I need (just a thought ;) )- graphics, are awesome, I have the game set to max quality settings and it's running at a steady 60 FPS on my rig (see below), there are a few minor FPS drops now and then, but nothing that ruins the game for me at least, I'm sure future optimization will eliminate most of these as wellSummary: So with the current state of the game and the options available to play, explore, build, etc. I can DEFINITELY recommend this game to anyone. It might not have crazy update schedule as other early access games (yes I'm looking at you ARK :P ), but these devs certainly are great when it comes to dedication and community interactions as far as I can tell anyway. Looking forward, to what you guys come up with next ;). Keep up the great work!!!UPDATE 01/23/15: So today the game was updated and I hopped in to check it out again. The graphics are great, the game runs smooth at max settings with my rig (i7 quad, 12GB RAM, GTX680 4GB RAM). Crafting is still something to get used to, especially if you play MC a lot like I do. I know they are trying to make it more intuitive I suppose, but it is really not. Just throwing stuff on the ground and then hoping something nice comes out of it, is not really intuitive. And the crafting system could be overlooked if you had some place to store all that stuff that you "accidently" craft. There is a backpack and a chest, both have no use... WHY!? how hard can it be to implement some more storage options for gods sake?I STILL believe this game has a great potential, but the devs seem unable to realize it... yet. There are so many survival games out there, check them out, see what they're doing wrong and what they're doing right AND maybe implement some of the "right" parts. What ... you call that stealing? Blizzard has been doing the same♥♥♥♥♥♥with WoW for a bloody decade!Get to it guys! I DO believe in you.===================================================================ORIGINAL: First off, the game has definitely potential, BUT at it's current stage I cannot recommend it to anyone, but the most die-hard early access fans, like myself :).  What annoys me personally the most is the lack of a proper inventory management. I like to collect as much **** as possible in these kinda games and TUGs inventory is ludicrously small. You can craft backpacks and chests, but they're only decoration right now. And the stack size of some items is laughable. I assume they are trying to make the game more realistic in that term, but hey ... it's a freaking game ... it DOESN'T have to be realistic. Or they're trying to make the game artificially more difficult by limiting your inventory, which is annoying as hell.  The good parts of the game right now is the crafting system. It take a bit getting used to for Minecrafters, like myself ;), but it is really good. It lacks the variety of recipes that Minecraft has, but I'm sure this will improve with time. I wish there was kinda like a crafting book, that would store recipes that I already discovered, so I don't have to place down all the items each time again and rather just click on the recipe in the book and it would place them for me.  Graphics are pretty good and it fits to the prehistoric (I assume that's what they're going for) very nicely. There are some hick-ups and glitches now and then, but nothing game breaking that I have discovered so far.  Combat system, I can't really tell, since I haven't found myself in combat yet. There are predators in the game and they're supposed to attack the player, but so far I only seen one and I kept far away from it.
